gamar2
  • Get Started
  • Reference

    Using gamar

    Introduction

    To be able to use gamar you need to install GAMA (> 1.7) on your system. You can do it from gama-platform.org. You then need to install the gamar R package, load it and configure it before you can use it. The gamar package contains 6 functions:

    • defpath to define the path to the GAMA executable
    • examples to manipulate examples from the built-in library
    • get_gaml to list the paths to the gaml models files in a hierarchy
    • get_experiment to list experiments of a gaml model file
    • experiment to create an object of class experiment
    • load_experiment to load an experiment of a model

    Installing gamar

    Before installing gamar you need to install the package devtools if not already installed on your system:

    > if (!"devtools" %in% rownames(installed.packages())) install.packages("devtools")

    Once devtools is installed on your system, you can install gamar directly from GitHub:

    > devtools::install_github("choisy/gamar")

    Loading and configuring gamar

    With gamar installed on your system, you need to load it before using it:

    > library(gamar)
Using the following GAMA executable: /Applications/Gama.app

    If you are using OS X or macOS, gamar will by default use the /Applications/Gama.app if it exists. If not, you can manually define the path to the GAMA with the defpath function:

    > defpath("path_to_your_GAMA_folder")

    Built-in models library

    There are a number of built-in examples in the gamar package, of which you can see the list:

    > examples()
sir           : An SIR epidemiological model.
predator-prey : A predator-prey model that includes vegetation growth and grazing by the prey.

    To use one of these examples, we recommand that you first move it to your local directory (by default):

    > dir()
character(0)
> examples("sir")
File 'sir.gaml' copied to working directory.
> dir()
[1] "sir.gaml"

    or to any other directory of your choice:

    > examples("sir", "one_directory")
File 'sir.gaml' copied to ./one_directory/sir.gaml.
> dir()
[1] "one_directory" "sir.gaml"     
> dir("one_directory")
[1] "sir.gaml"

    If a file with the same name already exists in the destination directory, the name of the copied file is appended a digit making it unique:

    > examples("sir", "one_directory")
File 'sir.gaml' copied to ./one_directory/sir1.gaml.
> dir("one_directory")
[1] "sir.gaml"  "sir1.gaml"

    The minimum that these examples include is a .gaml file that specifies the model and some experiment(s). Sometimes additional files are also included, for examples, shape files defining the space. That’s the case for the predator-prey model. All the files of the model are then contained in a directory:

    > dir()
[1] "one_directory" "sir.gaml"     
> examples("predator-prey")
Directory 'predator_prey' copied to working directory.
> dir("predator_prey", recursive = TRUE)
[1] "predator_prey/includes/data/raster_map.png"
[2] "predator_prey/includes/data/sheep.png"     
[3] "predator_prey/includes/data/soil.jpg"      
[4] "predator_prey/includes/data/wolf.png"      
[5] "predator_prey/includes/gis/Vegetation.dbf" 
[6] "predator_prey/includes/gis/Vegetation.shp" 
[7] "predator_prey/includes/gis/Vegetation.shx" 
[8] "predator_prey/models/predator_prey.gaml"

    Again, if the name of the directory already exists in the destination directory, the name of the directory is appended a digit making it unique:

    > examples("predator-prey")
Directory 'predator_prey' copied to ./predator_prey1.
> dir()
[1] "one_directory"  "predator_prey"  "predator_prey1" "sir.gaml"

    Last thing about this examples function is that you can copied several models at the same time:

    > examples(c("sir", "predator-prey"))
File 'sir.gaml' copied to ./sir1.gaml.
Directory 'predator_prey' copied to ./predator_prey2.

    specifying a common destination directory:

    > examples(c("sir", "predator-prey"), "common_directory")
File 'sir.gaml' copied to ./common_directory/sir.gaml.
Directory 'predator_prey' copied to ./common_directory/predator_prey.
> dir()
[1] "common_directory" "one_directory"    "predator_prey"   
[4] "predator_prey1"   "predator_prey2"   "sir.gaml"        
[7] "sir1.gaml"       
> dir("common_directory")
[1] "predator_prey" "sir.gaml"

    or a different directory for each model:

    > examples(c("sir", "predator-prey"), c("directory1", "directory2"))
File 'sir.gaml' copied to ./directory1/sir.gaml.
Directory 'predator_prey' copied to ./directory2/predator_prey.
> dir()
[1] "common_directory" "directory1"       "directory2"      
[4] "one_directory"    "predator_prey"    "predator_prey1"  
[7] "predator_prey2"   "sir.gaml"         "sir1.gaml"       
> dir("directory1")
[1] "sir.gaml"
> dir("directory2")
[1] "predator_prey"

    Loading experiments

    Listing the GAMA models in a file hierarchy:

    > (mod <- list_gaml("predator_prey"))
[1] "predator_prey/predator_prey/models/predator_prey.gaml"

    The argument to get_gaml is the path to the top of a file hierarchy. By default, it’s the current directory. Listing the experiments of a GAMA model:

    > list_experiment(mod)
[1] "prey_predator" "Optimization"

    Loading a model from an experiment:

    > predprey <- load_experiment("prey_predator", mod)  # creates workgamar with sir_1.xml in it
Loading experiment 'prey_predator' from file 'predator_prey.gaml'...

    Similarly with the SIR model:

    > dir()
[1] "common_directory" "directory1"       "directory2"      
[4] "one_directory"    "predator_prey"    "predator_prey1"  
[7] "predator_prey2"   "sir.gaml"         "sir1.gaml"       
> list_experiment("sir.gaml")
[1] "sir"
> sir_exp <- load_experiment("sir", "sir.gaml")
Loading experiment 'sir' from file 'sir.gaml'...

    TO DO: loading several experiments from a same model GAMA file.

    > class(sir_exp)
[1] "plan"

    print method:

    > sir_exp

A plan of experiments of the process model defined in:
/Users/choisy/using_gamar/sir.gaml 

Parameters values of each of the single set of experiments of the plan:
   S0 I0 R0 beta gamma
1 999  1  0  1.5  0.15


Periods (in number of steps) at which variables are monitored:
S I R 
1 1 1 

Number of steps in the simulations: 1000 

This 'set of experiments' here actually corresponds to only 1 simulation performed with the seed 1

    Underlying list structure:

    > is.list(sir_exp)
[1] TRUE
> str(sir_exp)
List of 5
 $ parameters:'data.frame': 1 obs. of  5 variables:
  ..$ S0   : num 999
  ..$ I0   : num 1
  ..$ R0   : num 0
  ..$ beta : num 1.5
  ..$ gamma: num 0.15
 $ variables : Named int [1:3] 1 1 1
  ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:3] "S" "I" "R"
 $ nbsteps   : int 1000
 $ model     : chr "/Users/choisy/using_gamar/sir.gaml"
 $ seeds     : int 1
 - attr(*, "class")= chr "plan"
> names(sir_exp)
[1] "parameters" "variables"  "nbsteps"    "model"      "seeds"

    Manipulating experiments

    Values of an experiment can be changed as for any list

    > sir_exp$parameters["I0"]
  I0
1  1
> sir_exp$parameters["I0"] <- 10
> sir_exp$parameters["I0"]
  I0
1 10

    Editing the model:

    > edit_model(sir_exp)
